tier_0_classification.classification_reasoning: The question requires calculating the amplitude after two cycles given the damping ratio and initial displacement. It involves understanding the concept of damped oscillations and applying the logarithmic decrement formula, requiring multiple steps. The difficulty is medium because it requires applying a specific formula and understanding its parameters.

answer_validation.reasoning:
For an underdamped SDOF system with viscous damping ratio \(\zeta = 0.1\), the displacement envelope decays as \(x(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t}\) (ignoring the sinusoidal factor for peak amplitudes). The damped period is \(T_d =  rac{2\pi}{\omega_d}\), where \(\omega_d = \omega_n \sqrt{1-\zeta^2}\). After two complete damped cycles, \(t = 2T_d\). The ratio of amplitudes after \(n\) cycles is \( rac{X_n}{X_0} = e^{-\zeta \omega_n n T_d} = e^{-\zeta \omega_n n  rac{2\pi}{\omega_d}} = e^{- rac{2\pi n \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}}\). For \(n = 2\) and \(\zeta = 0.1\): 

\(\delta =  rac{2\pi \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}} =  rac{2\pi(0.1)}{\sqrt{1-0.01}} \approx  rac{0.2\pi}{0.99499} \approx 0.631\).

After two cycles, exponent is \(2\delta \approx 1.262\). Thus, \( rac{X_2}{X_0} = e^{-2\delta} = e^{-1.262} \approx 0.283\). With initial amplitude \(X_0 = 10\,	ext{cm}\), \(X_2 \approx 10 	imes 0.283 = 2.83\,	ext{cm}\). This lies within the official key range 2.80 to 2.86, confirming the answer.

step_by_step: Step 1: Note given data: viscous damping ratio \(\zeta = 0.1\), initial displacement (initial amplitude) \(X_0 = 10\,\text{cm}\), and zero initial velocity. We need amplitude after 2 damped cycles (time \(2T_d\)).

Step 2: For an underdamped SDOF system, the displacement is \(x(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t} \cos(\omega_d t + \phi)\). The peak amplitudes follow the exponential envelope \(X(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t}\).
Step 3: The damped natural frequency is \(\omega_d = \omega_n \sqrt{1-\zeta^2}\), so the damped period is \(T_d = \frac{2\pi}{\omega_d}\). After \(n\) cycles, \(t = nT_d\).

Step 4: Amplitude after \(n\) cycles: \(X_n = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n n T_d} = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n n \frac{2\pi}{\omega_d}} = X_0 e^{-\frac{2\pi n \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}}\). This is the standard logarithmic decrement relation.

Step 5: Compute the logarithmic decrement per cycle: \(\delta = \frac{2\pi \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}\). For \(\zeta = 0.1\), \(\sqrt{1-\zeta^2} = \sqrt{0.99} \approx 0.99499\), so \(\delta \approx \frac{2\pi(0.1)}{0.99499} \approx 0.631\).
Step 6: After two cycles, exponent is \(2\delta \approx 1.262\). Thus, \(\frac{X_2}{X_0} = e^{-2\delta} = e^{-1.262} \approx 0.283\).

Step 7: Multiply by initial amplitude: \(X_2 = 10\,\text{cm} \times 0.283 \approx 2.83\,\text{cm}\). Rounded to two decimal places, this is 2.83 cm, which lies in the official acceptable range 2.80 to 2.86 cm.

topic.name: Mechanical Vibrations of Single Degree of Freedom Systems
topic.syllabus_ref: Section: Structures and Vibrations -> Free and forced vibrations of single degree of freedom systems

concepts.name: Damped free vibration of SDOF systems

essential: Understanding of single degree of freedom spring-mass-damper model
Concept of viscous damping and damping ratio \(\zeta\)
Relationship between undamped and damped natural frequencies
Logarithmic decrement and amplitude decay in damped vibration
helpful: Ability to manipulate exponentials and natural logarithms
Familiarity with underdamped, critically damped, and overdamped cases

Main Concept: requires: single degree of freedom vibration modeling
requires: definition of damping ratio and damped natural frequency
requires: derivation of exponential decay envelope and logarithmic decrement
enables: experimental determination of damping from measured amplitudes
enables: design of vibration isolation and damping in aerospace structures

difficulty_factors: Requires recalling the correct logarithmic decrement formula relating amplitude ratio to damping ratio
Involves careful handling of exponentials and multiple cycles (n = 2)

textbook_references.author: S. S. Rao
textbook_references.section: Damped Free Vibration and Logarithmic Decrement

textbook_references.author: Singiresu S. Rao
textbook_references.section: Logarithmic decrement and experimental determination of damping
textbook_references.text_snippet: Logarithmic decrement (delta) is an experimental method used to determine the damping ratio (zeta) of an underdamped vibratory system. It quantifies the rate at which the amplitude of free vibration decays by measuring the ratio of successive amplitudes.

video_references.topic_covered: Logarithmic decrement and experimental determination of damping ratio
Example problem on natural frequency, damping ratio, and logarithmic decrement

step_by_step_solution.solution_path: Identify underdamped SDOF system \u2192 Use exponential decay/logarithmic decrement relation \u2192 Compute decrement from damping ratio \u2192 Apply for two cycles to get amplitude
key_insights: Peak amplitudes in underdamped vibration follow an exponential decay envelope independent of the cosine term.
The ratio of successive amplitudes depends only on damping ratio via logarithmic decrement, not on mass or stiffness.
For \(n\) cycles, the amplitude scales as \(e^{-n\delta}\), so here \(n = 2\).

formulas_principles.name: Equation of motion for damped SDOF free vibration
formulas_principles.conditions: Linear viscous damping, single degree of freedom, free vibration (no external force)
formulas_principles.relevance: Governing equation whose solution leads to exponential decay and damped oscillation.

formulas_principles.name: Damped natural frequency
formulas_principles.relevance: Used to relate damped period to undamped natural frequency and damping ratio.

formulas_principles.name: Logarithmic decrement
formulas_principles.relevance: Core formula to compute amplitude decay per cycle from damping ratio.

formulas_principles.name: Amplitude after n cycles
formulas_principles.conditions: Underdamped SDOF, logarithmic decrement defined as above
formulas_principles.relevance: Directly used to find amplitude after two cycles from initial amplitude.

industry_examples: Design of landing gear shock absorbers where damping ratio determines how quickly oscillations die out after touchdown.
Vibration control in aircraft wings and control surfaces to ensure oscillations decay within acceptable cycles after a gust.
specific_systems: Main landing gear oleo struts of commercial airliners
real_world_applications.practical_relevance: Knowing how amplitude decays over cycles allows engineers to specify damping so that structural vibrations die out quickly, avoiding passenger discomfort, structural fatigue, or aeroelastic instabilities.

common_mistakes.mistake: Using \(e^{-2\pi \zeta}\) directly for amplitude after two cycles instead of \(e^{-\frac{2\pi n \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}}\), i.e., forgetting the \(\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}\) term.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They recall a simplified relation for very small damping and omit the exact dependence on damped frequency.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Memorize the full formula for logarithmic decrement \(\delta = \frac{2\pi \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}\) and always check if \(\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}\) is present.
common_mistakes.consequence: Leads to an overestimation of decay and a significantly smaller amplitude than correct.

common_mistakes.mistake: Confusing number of cycles with time and using \(t = 2T_n\) (undamped period) instead of \(t = 2T_d\) (damped period).
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They are more familiar with undamped natural period and forget that the problem explicitly mentions damped period.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Underline 'damped period' in the question and recall that cycles in a damped system are based on \(T_d = 2\pi/\omega_d\).
common_mistakes.consequence: Gives a slightly different exponent and hence a wrong amplitude.

common_mistakes.mistake: Treating 10 cm as 10 m or converting units unnecessarily and then forgetting to convert back to cm.
common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: Automatic habit of converting to SI units even when not needed for a ratio-based calculation.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Notice that amplitude ratio is dimensionless; you can keep units in cm throughout and only ensure final answer is in cm.
common_mistakes.consequence: Can lead to answers off by a factor of 100 if unit conversion is mishandled.

common_mistakes.why_students_make_it: They remember that decay depends on \(\zeta\) but forget the full derivation and constants.
common_mistakes.how_to_avoid: Derive the relation once from \(x(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t}\) and \(T_d = 2\pi/\omega_d\) so the constants stick conceptually.
common_mistakes.consequence: Produces a much smaller exponent and incorrect amplitude.

mnemonics_memory_aids.context: Use when recalling how damping ratio relates to amplitude decay per cycle.

mnemonics_memory_aids.concept: Use \(T_d = 2\pi/\omega_d\) when counting cycles in a damped system
mnemonics_memory_aids.context: When a question mentions number of cycles in a damped system.

flashcards.front: What is the expression for logarithmic decrement \(\delta\) in an underdamped SDOF system in terms of damping ratio \(\zeta\)?
How does the peak amplitude of an underdamped SDOF system vary with time?
flashcards.back: Peak amplitudes follow the exponential envelope: \(X(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t}\), where \(\zeta\) is damping ratio and \(\omega_n\) is undamped natural frequency.

flashcards.front: An SDOF system has \(\zeta = 0.1\). If initial amplitude is 10 cm, what is amplitude after 1 cycle (approx)?
flashcards.back: First compute \(\delta = \frac{2\pi(0.1)}{\sqrt{1-0.01}} \approx 0.631\). After 1 cycle, \(X_1 = X_0 e^{-\delta} \approx 10 e^{-0.631} \approx 5.33\,\text{cm}.\)

flashcards.front: When finding amplitude after n damped cycles, which period should you use: \(T_n\) or \(T_d\)?
flashcards.back: Always use the damped period \(T_d = 2\pi/\omega_d\). Cycles in a damped system are based on \(\omega_d\), not \(\omega_n\).

flashcards.front: Define logarithmic decrement in the context of damped vibrations.
flashcards.back: Logarithmic decrement \(\delta\) is the natural logarithm of the ratio of any two successive peak amplitudes in an underdamped system: \(\delta = \ln(X_n/X_{n+1})\).

real_world_context.application: Decay of landing gear oscillations after aircraft touchdown
real_world_context.industry_example: If the damping ratio is chosen so that oscillations reduce to about 30% of initial amplitude after two cycles, passengers feel a quick but smooth settling after landing.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Too little damping leads to prolonged bouncing; too much can cause harsh impacts and high loads.

real_world_context.application: Vibration of satellite appendages (like solar panels) after deployment
real_world_context.industry_example: Engineers specify damping so that panel tip deflection reduces to a small fraction within a few cycles to avoid interference with instruments.
real_world_context.why_it_matters: Insufficient damping can cause long-lasting oscillations that affect pointing accuracy and structural integrity.

exam_strategy.triage_tip: Identify it as a standard damped vibration/logarithmic decrement problem. If you remember \(\delta = \frac{2\pi \zeta}{\sqrt{1-\zeta^2}}\), it is a quick plug-in and exponent calculation.
exam_strategy.guessing_heuristic: If stuck, note that \(\zeta = 0.1\) is small, so amplitude after 2 cycles should be a few tens of percent of initial (not near 0 or near 10). Pick a value around 2â€“4 cm.
exam_strategy.time_management: Allocate about 2 minutes: 1 minute to recall/write formulas and 1 minute for numerical calculation and rounding.

search_keywords: single degree of freedom vibration tutorial

alternative_methods.name: Successive amplitude ratio method
alternative_methods.description: Instead of using the closed-form \(X_n = X_0 e^{-n\delta}\), compute the ratio per cycle: \(X_{k+1} = X_k e^{-\delta}\). For two cycles, apply it twice: \(X_1 = X_0 e^{-\delta}\), then \(X_2 = X_1 e^{-\delta} = X_0 e^{-2\delta}\).
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Conceptually simple, mirrors experimental procedure of measuring successive peaks. Cons: Still requires \(\delta\) formula; not more efficient than direct \(n\delta\) approach.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: Useful when you are given or measuring successive amplitudes experimentally and want to relate them stepwise.

alternative_methods.name: Direct time-domain approach using \(x(t)\)
alternative_methods.description: Write \(x(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t} \cos(\omega_d t)\) with \(\phi = 0\) (since initial displacement and zero velocity). Determine the time of the second peak (approximately at \(t \approx 2T_d\)) and evaluate the envelope \(X(t) = X_0 e^{-\zeta \omega_n t}\) at that time.
alternative_methods.pros_cons: Pros: Reinforces understanding of the full time response. Cons: More algebraic steps; essentially reduces to the same exponential factor as the logarithmic decrement method.
alternative_methods.when_to_use: When deriving the amplitude decay relation from first principles or checking the consistency of the logarithmic decrement formula.

connections_to_other_subjects.Flight Mechanics: Vibration of aircraft structures (e.g., short-period and phugoid modes) can be modeled as damped oscillators; damping ratio determines how quickly attitude perturbations decay.
connections_to_other_subjects.Control Systems: Second-order system step responses use the same parameters \(\zeta\) and \(\omega_n\); overshoot and settling time are directly related to damping ratio and exponential decay.
connections_to_other_subjects.Space Dynamics: Attitude control of satellites often involves damping of flexible modes, modeled as SDOF damped oscillators.
connections_to_other_subjects.Materials and Structures: Structural damping in beams and panels is characterized similarly, affecting fatigue life and dynamic response.

deeper_dive_topics: Experimental determination of damping ratio using logarithmic decrement from measured time histories
Effect of different damping models (Coulomb, structural, hysteretic) on amplitude decay
Multi-degree-of-freedom damped vibration and modal damping ratios
Random vibration and how damping affects response spectra

syllabus_mapping.gate_subsection: Free and forced vibrations of single degree of freedom systems, damping, logarithmic decrement
syllabus_mapping.feedback_for_syllabus_design: The question is a direct and fair test of core SDOF damped vibration concepts, especially logarithmic decrement and damping ratio, which are explicitly listed in the syllabus.

rag_quality.notes: RAG provided several video-note chunks on damped free vibration, equation of motion, and especially logarithmic decrement and example problems. These directly support the solution approach (using damping ratio to find amplitude decay). The exact multi-cycle amplitude formula was not explicitly given but follows standard derivations consistent with the RAG content.

future_questions_potential: Given measured successive amplitudes from an experiment, compute the damping ratio using logarithmic decrement.
For a given mass and stiffness, find the damping coefficient corresponding to a specified amplitude reduction after N cycles.
Compare amplitude decay for two systems with different damping ratios and discuss which is better for a given aerospace application.
Extend to forced vibration: determine steady-state amplitude near resonance for a given damping ratio and forcing frequency.

response_json.subject: Aerospace Engineering
response_json.question_text: A single degree-of-freedom spring-mass-damper system has viscous damping ratio of 0.1. The mass is given an initial displacement of 10 cm without imparting any velocity. After exactly two complete cycles of oscillation (i.e., after time 2T_d, where T_d is the period of the damped vibration), the amplitude of the displacement is ______ cm. (round off to two decimal place)
